title: Ben Jrada Mohammed Es-salih
text:
I am a Postdoctoral Researcher in Statistics and Data Science with research interests at the intersection of
non-parametric inference, inverse problems, and shape-constrained estimation.
My work combines rigorous theoretical analysis with methodological development and applications to real-world data, with a particular focus on measurement error models, deconvolution techniques, and survival analysis.

title: Ben Jrada Mohammed Es-salih
text:
Welcome
Welcome to my personal academic website.
I am a Postdoctoral Researcher in Statistics and Data Science, with research interests at the intersection of non-parametric statistics, inverse problems, and shape-constrained inference. My work combines rigorous theoretical analysis with methodological development and applications to real-world data.

title: Ben Jrada Mohammed Es-salih
text:
Research Interests

Non-parametric estimation and hypothesis testing under measurement error

Inverse problems and deconvolution-based methods

Shape-constrained estimation and inference

Asymptotic theory and empirical process methods

Statistical computing, simulations, and reproducible research in R

title: Ben Jrada Mohammed Es-salih
text:
Background
I hold a PhD in Statistics, with a doctoral thesis devoted to the estimation of the hazard rate function under additive measurement error. My work established theoretical properties of the proposed estimators, including convergence results and asymptotic distributions, and demonstrated their performance on real survival data.
I have over five years of experience in statistical data analysis and methodological research, with strong expertise in R programming, simulation-based studies, and data visualization.

title: Ben Jrada Mohammed Es-salih
text:
Current Work
My current research focuses on:

Development of non-parametric tests under additive noise

Deconvolution-based and shape-constrained estimation methods

title: About Me
text:
I am a statistician and postdoctoral researcher specializing in non-parametric inference, with strong expertise in inverse problems and deconvolution methods. My research combines theoretical rigor with practical implementation, aiming to develop robust statistical methodologies for data contaminated by measurement error.
My work spans shape-constrained estimation, asymptotic theory, and simulation-based inference, with a particular focus on applications in survival analysis and reliability theory.
I have extensive experience in statistical computing using R, including methodological development, simulation studies, and data visualization, and I actively engage in interdisciplinary research collaborations.

title: Ben Jrada Mohammed Es-salih
text:
Research Profile
I hold a PhD in Statistics, with a doctoral thesis devoted to the estimation of the hazard rate function under additive measurement error. My research established theoretical properties of non-parametric estimators, including convergence results, asymptotic distributions, and almost sure behavior, and demonstrated their performance on real survival data.
I have over five years of experience in statistical research and data analysis, with strong expertise in R programming, simulation-based studies, and data visualization. I actively collaborate across disciplines and contribute to the development of robust statistical tools for contaminated data.

title: Research
text:
My research lies at the intersection of non-parametric statistics, inverse problems, and shape-constrained inference, with a strong emphasis on theoretical foundations and methodological development motivated by real data applications.
I am particularly interested in statistical inference under measurement error, where classical procedures fail and deconvolution-based techniques are required. My work combines kernel methods, Fourier techniques, and asymptotic theory to construct estimators and tests with provable guarantees.

title: Research
text:
My research lies at the intersection of non-parametric statistics, inverse problems, and shape-constrained inference, with a strong emphasis on theoretical foundations and methodological development motivated by real data applications.
I am particularly interested in statistical inference under measurement error, where classical procedures fail and deconvolution-based techniques are required. My work combines kernel methods, Fourier techniques, and asymptotic theory to construct estimators and tests with provable guarantees.

title: Research
text:
Main Research Themes

üîπ Non-Parametric Estimation under Measurement Error
A central part of my research focuses on estimating distributional and functional characteristics when observations are contaminated by additive noise. This includes:

Density and distribution function estimation via deconvolution
Hazard rate estimation under error-in-variables models
Study of quadratic mean, almost sure, and weak convergence
Bandwidth selection and bias‚Äìvariance trade-offs

These problems naturally arise in reliability analysis, survival analysis, and applied economics.



üîπ Inverse Problems and Deconvolution Methods
Inverse problems form the theoretical backbone of my work. I investigate:

Ill-posedness in statistical inverse problems
Regularization through kernel and Fourier-based approaches
Noise-to-signal ratio (NSR) effects on estimator performance
Minimax rates and asymptotic distributions

Special attention is given to Gamma, Gaussian, and Laplace noise structures, motivated by applied contexts.



üîπ Shape-Constrained Inference
I am actively working on shape constraints as a way to improve efficiency and interpretability of estimators, including:

Monotonicity and convexity constraints
Shape-constrained CDF and hazard rate estimation
Constrained vs unconstrained estimator comparisons
Projection-based methods under noise contamination

These ideas are currently explored in the context of deconvolution-based tests.



üîπ Non-Parametric Testing
My recent work includes the development of non-parametric hypothesis tests under measurement error, such as:

Monotonicity testing using the Total Time on Test (TTT) transform
Simulation-based power analysis
Bootstrap and asymptotic calibration
Applications to lifetime and reliability data

title: Research
text:
Applications and Data Analysis
Although my work is theoretically grounded, I maintain a strong interest in applications, particularly in:

Reliability and survival data
Economic and environmental datasets
Simulation studies to validate asymptotic results

I regularly use R for implementation, visualization, and reproducible research, with a focus on clean, modular, and extensible code.

title: Research
text:
Current and Ongoing Projects

Non-parametric tests under additive noise
Development of monotonicity tests using deconvolution and shape constraints.
Shape-constrained CDF estimation under Gamma noise
Performance comparison via MSE and asymptotic analysis.
Inverse problems in reliability analysis
Estimation of hazard functions with provable convergence properties.

title: Research
text:

Non-parametric statistics
Kernel smoothing & Fourier transforms
Deconvolution techniques
Shape-constrained estimation
Asymptotic theory
Simulation studies
R (advanced statistical computing and visualization)
